content.title: TECHNOLOGICAL SOLUTIONS
content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 3 | Lesson 2

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview

Both new and existing technological developments can play a pivotal role in shaping the landscape of energy generation and transformation, as well as improving energy efficiency. This is particularly critical in remote communities, where access to energy remains a significant challenge. This lesson outlines some of the key technological solutions that can accelerate the path towards universal energy access, while also supporting the transition to clean energy systems.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: e-cooking
concepts.body: E-cooking refers to the use of electric appliances and devices for cooking food, which can include methods such as induction cooking, electric ovens, and microwaves, often emphasizing energy efficiency and sustainability.

concepts.title: mini-grids
concepts.body: Mini-grids are small-scale power generation and distribution systems that can operate independently or in conjunction with the main electrical grid, providing electricity to local communities, often in remote or underserved areas.

concepts.title: off-grid renewable energy systems
concepts.body: Off-grid renewable energy systems are energy setups that generate power independently from the traditional electricity grid, using renewable sources like solar, wind, or hydro, to provide energy for homes or communities.

content.text: Renewable energy, particularly Solar PV, is key to closing the energy gap. With an expected 2050 GW solar capacity by 2027, it is a game-changer for unelectrified regions (UNDP, 2023). From the people currently lacking access to electricity, around 59% (396 million people) can benefit from solar mini-grids, 30% (203 million people) via grid extensions, and 11% (77 million people) through Decentralized Renewable Energy solutions (DRE) (UNDP, 2023).

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 3 | Lesson 2 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Off-grid renewable energy systems

content.text: Part 1 Overview

Decentralized solutions provide a cost-effective, quickly deployable alternative to grid expansion, addressing lower-demand areas while supporting productive uses such as solar water pumps, refrigeration, and equipment for microenterprises. These applications drive socioeconomic development, increase productivity, and support job creation and economic growth in rural communities (IEA; 2024).

As of 2021, approximately 101 million people worldwide had access to electricity through stand-alone off-grid solar solutions (IEA., 2023). Looking ahead, off-grid solar technologies hold substantial promise for expanding electricity access. Projections indicate that by 2030, off-grid solar solutions could provide first-time electricity access to nearly 400 million people globally, accounting for about 41% of those expected to remain without electricity under current trajectories (ESMAP.,2024). Off-grid renewable energy systems have proven to be one of the best-known solutions to expanding energy access especially in underserved rural areas (Babayomi et. al., 2022). This category encompasses a diverse array of solutions that are reshaping the provision of reliable electricity, particularly in remote and underserved regions. Solar home systems and mini-grids play a crucial role in providing electrical access.
Solar Home Systems

Solar Home Systems, often abbreviated as SHS, are portable, stand-alone solar power units that usher in a new era of clean and reliable electricity. SHS are portable, stand-alone solar power units that offer clean and reliable electricity to areas with sporadic or no grid access, particularly in regions with abundant sunlight, such as sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia, and Latin America. These systems are more affordable than mini-grids and are suitable for low-density areas or individual households.
Mini-grids

Mini-grids are decentralized energy distribution systems that connect multiple users to a central power source. Mini-grids can integrate diverse renewable energy sources, such as solar panels and wind generators, to optimize available intermittent energy sources. Although mini-grids require a higher initial investment, they offer the advantage of shared capacity, reducing the need for higher peak capacities.
Example in Bangladesh.

Bangladesh demonstrates the successful deployment of these technologies. By harnessing solar power, a program has enabled 20 million Bangladeshis to access electricity, with 5.6 million Solar Home Systems (SHS) installed in off-grid rural areas (WBG, 2021a). The Second Rural Electrification and Renewable Energy Development Project in Bangladesh has installed 26 solar mini-grids, benefiting over 8,000 households and businesses, and 1,130 solar irrigation pumps, which have supported 35,000 farmers (WBG, 2021b)
Technologies enabling innovation

Complementary technologies are driving energy access further, with innovations such as smart meters, energy-efficient appliances, and advanced battery storage systems, all contributing to expanding energy access on a global scale. Smart meters enhance universal energy access by enabling precise energy usage monitoring, reducing waste, and facilitating pay-as-you-go systems for affordability. While smart meters make pay-as-you-go easier by allowing real-time tracking and remote disconnection or reconnection, pay-as-you-go systems themselves predate smart meters and are essentially prepayment models that allow lower-income households to purchase electricity in small, manageable increments. Energy-efficient appliances lower energy demand, making off-grid systems more viable and reducing costs for underserved communities. Advanced battery storage systems ensure reliable energy availability, storing surplus from renewable sources to provide consistent power in off-grid settings.
Example: The Hakwata microgrid project

As part of UNDP's Smart Facilities initiative Hakwata village in Zimbabwe is being equipped with a solar microgrid. This system will provide reliable, clean electricity to over 80 households as well as a local clinic, school and shops. With battery storage, it ensures uninterrupted electricity even during periods of low sunlight and at night. Additionally, solar energy will drive borehole pumps at schools, clinics, and local shops to provide clean water. This project exemplifies how communities can adopt clean energy solutions that contributes to improving infrastructure and enhancing the quality of life in rural areas, offering a scalable model for sustainable energy adoption across the country.

content.title: Part 2: Advancing Clean Cooking

content.text: Part 2 Overview

Clean cooking solutions provide transformative alternatives to traditional methods, tackling health, environmental, and gender disparities in underserved communities. This section highlights two promising modern approaches: biogas and e-cooking, showcasing their potential to enhance sustainability and improve livelihoods.
Biogas

Biogas systems, a renewable energy source derived from organic materials, are an increasingly viable option for off-grid rural communities. Small-scale systems can be directly used for cooking and heating, while larger systems can generate electricity to meet additional household, community, and productive energy needs, such as agricultural processing. Biogas, produced from agricultural residues and waste, offers a promising solution for both renewable energy and improved waste management. The technology can mitigate greenhouse gas emissions, reduce environmental pollution, and generate sustainable energy while creating economic opportunities. These systems are especially suitable for regions with abundant organic waste, such as agricultural areas or communities involved in livestock farming. Biogas technologies are also particularly relevant in areas that need integrated strategies to address land degradation, climate change mitigation, and energy access. Successful biogas systems require a steady supply of organic waste, such as animal manure or food scraps, to feed the digester. Moreover, the design of the digesters must be scaled according to the size of the community, with the dimensioning accounting for fluctuations in gas production due to variations in waste availability and environmental conditions.
Examples in Botswana and Rwanda

For instance, biogas plants have been successfully deployed in countries like Botswana and Rwanda (UNDP, 2023a; UNDP, 2023b), enabling communities to generate energy locally while also managing waste: The UNDP Biogas Project in Botswana promotes the use of biogas from agro-waste, such as cow dung and chicken litter, for cooking, heating, lighting, and electricity. The project is implemented by the Botswana Institute for Technology Research and Innovation (BITRI) and focuses on three key components: capacity building, the establishment of biogas plants, and the development of biogas utilization platforms. The initiative encourages low-carbon investments, public-private partnerships, and policy advocacy in South-eastern Botswana, supporting national goals to improve energy security, increase renewable energy, and reduce the country’s carbon footprint. In Rwanda, the Homebiogas project, led by UNDP, provides a sustainable solution to the clean cooking energy challenge, improving safety for women and reducing deforestation. The biogas units, powered by cow dung, provide up to six hours of cooking per day and produce fertilizer for farming. The technology is low-maintenance, self-sustaining, and lasts up to 10 years, with local engineers and families trained to maintain the systems. Financing is also supported through carbon markets and government contributions. The project has been tested in 500 households, with plans to expand to one million, offering a key opportunity to address Rwanda’s cooking energy crisis and promote sustainability.
e-cooking solutions

E-cooking solutions, particularly solar-powered cooking technologies, present an innovative and increasingly cost-effective alternative to traditional cooking methods. These solutions have become more viable due to improved electricity access and decreasing costs of solar photovoltaic technologies. The payback period for solar e-cooking systems is rapidly shortening, typically ranging from 2-4 years (WBG, 2024). Solar e-cooking offers significant greenhouse gas emissions savings, with each stove reducing 2-4 tonnes of CO2 emissions annually. These technologies also offer the potential for carbon finance through international carbon markets, contributing to climate change mitigation efforts. Potential earnings from carbon finance can range from USD 20-100 per year (WBG, 2024).
Example: Ghana eCookbook and the importance of cultural validation

Increasing access to clean cooking goes beyond providing clean cooking fuels and technologies. Cultural validation during design development is central to technology adoption. Cooking symbolizes one's culture and community identity, and therefore interventions must place the needs of the community first (IEA, 2023). Investing in a sustainable domestic supply chain is critical in this endeavor, boosting local production and innovative solutions aligned with local cooking culture and available resources. For example, in Ghana, where research revealed apprehensions regarding the compatibility of traditional Ghanaian cuisine with modern energy-efficient appliances, initiatives such as "Ghana eCookbook: Exploring Electric Cooking" showcased the feasibility of preparing traditional Ghanaian dishes using electric cookstoves.

content.title: Part 3: Heating and Cooling Solutions

content.text: Part 3 Overview

Renewable technologies are proving versatile in addressing essential needs beyond electricity. For example, solar-powered water heaters and bioclimatic construction methods can provide access to sanitary hot water, and heating and cooling for housing, traditionally met through conventional energy sources. Additionally, technologies such as solar dryers are playing a vital role in reducing post-harvest losses in agro-processing and preserving fish and other perishable goods, contributing to food security and improved livelihoods in rural communities.

Renewable technologies are proving versatile in addressing essential needs beyond electricity. For example, solar-powered water heaters and bioclimatic construction methods can provide access to sanitary hot water, and heating and cooling for housing, traditionally met through conventional energy sources. Additionally, technologies such as solar dryers are playing a vital role in reducing post-harvest losses in agro-processing and preserving fish and other perishable goods, contributing to food security and improved livelihoods in rural communities.

One of the most effective renewable technologies for heating is the solar-powered water heater, which uses the sun’s energy to heat water for domestic and commercial use. These systems consist of solar panels that capture solar radiation and convert it into thermal energy, which is then used to heat water stored in a tank. Solar water heaters are highly effective in regions with abundant sunlight, making them an ideal solution for many parts of the world. They can be used in a wide range of applications, including household use, commercial buildings, and industrial processes that require hot water.

Bioclimatic building technologies integrate design principles that use local climate and natural elements to improve thermal comfort. Strategies such as passive solar heating, natural ventilation, and shading can reduce the reliance on external energy sources for temperature control. By aligning housing design with the surrounding climate, these approaches not only improve energy efficiency but also decrease the demand for additional heating or cooling. Furthermore, bioclimatic buildings are designed with insulation and energy-efficient windows to reduce heat loss or gain, improving the overall energy efficiency of the home. Geothermal energy, which harnesses the Earth's internal heat, is another renewable energy technology with promising applications for heating and cooling. In geothermal heating systems, heat is extracted from the Earth through wells or ground heat exchangers and used to warm buildings or water. In cooling applications, geothermal systems can function as heat pumps, providing a cooling effect by transferring heat from inside a building to the ground.

Solar-powered freezers and cold rooms are essential for preserving perishable goods in off-grid and remote areas where reliable electricity is often unavailable. These systems utilize solar energy to provide cooling, ensuring that food and other temperature-sensitive items are kept fresh without the need for conventional electricity. Solar-powered cold storage solutions are particularly beneficial for small-scale farmers, fishers, and vendors, as they reduce food waste, extend shelf life, and improve the income potential of local businesses. These technologies can also help communities in developing regions store surplus produce, contributing to food security and economic stability.
Examples

In Sierra Leone, UNDP has initiated a nationwide distribution of solar-powered freezers to nearly two hundred women's groups across the country, aiming to support their economic empowerment and improve their livelihoods. This initiative allows women to store and preserve food more effectively, which enhances their ability to sell products, expand their businesses, and increase their income opportunities (UNDP Sierra Leone, 2024). In Liberia, through its Livelihood & Employment Creation Project, UNDP procured two forty-foot solar-powered prefab facilities and eight solar freezers. These innovative systems provide an affordable and sustainable solution for vegetable sellers and fishers, improving their income generation and contributing to food security. The solar-powered prefab containers and freezers use renewable solar energy to operate at much lower costs than grid electricity, making them an ideal solution for rural and off-grid areas (UNDP Liberia, 2024).

content.title: Case Study : Africa

content.text: The Africa Minigrids Program (AMP), a collaborative initiative led by UNDP with support from GEF funding, Rocky Mountain Institute (RMI), and the African Development Bank (AfDB), is actively addressing the need for clean energy access in 21 African countries. Leveraging cost-effective minigrids, it aims to electrify 265 million people by 2030, presenting a $65 billion investment opportunity, predominantly from the private sector. AMP's primary objective is to promote access to clean energy by reducing costs, fostering innovative business models, and attracting increased commercial investment in renewable energy minigrids. For example, in countries such as Burkina Faso and Malawi, solar mini-grids are powering rural electrification and democratizing vital services like healthcare and education through the AMP projects. Additionally, south-south cooperation emerges as a powerful tool for SDG7. For example, Ethiopia, in partnership with China and Sri Lanka, is actively closing the energy access gap, facilitating a transition to a jobs-rich green economy through collaborative efforts (UNDP, 2023) Scroll below gently and play the video that will appear for an overview of this initiative:
SDG Interlinkages in the AMP

The AMP aligns with SDG 7 (Affordable and Clean Energy) by enhancing access to clean energy in underserved regions. By promoting innovative business models and cost reductions, the program contributes to SDG 1 (No Poverty) and SDG 8 (Decent Work and Economic Growth) through improved income opportunities and economic growth. Additionally, the AMP's potential to electrify schools, clinics, and businesses aligns with SDG 4 (Quality Education), SDG 3 (Good Health and Well-being), and SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure).
(Optional) See more details on the AMG - click to expand

Focused on early-stage minigrid markets, the AMG program aims to establish a conducive environment for private investment, emphasizing the financial viability and commercial scalability of renewable energy minigrids. The program's multi-partner approach involves collaboration with various stakeholders to maximize impact and complement ongoing efforts to develop minigrid markets across Africa. The AMP started its implementation in 2022 and will continue until 2027. The program has a country-based focus, while also maximizing opportunities for South-South/Triangular Cooperation and providing backstopping through an organized “chapeau” project. It is structured into two main components: a Regional Project functioning as a 'Knowledge Management' platform and 21 National Projects, each tailored to specific country contexts. The Regional Project is structured as a ‘Knowledge Management’ platform, to support the program’s National Projects, and the Africa minigrids market more generally, through four core sets of activities: Knowledge tools for both public and private actors. Tailored technical assistance to countries. Specialized regional Communities of Practice. Support for digitalization in the minigrids market. The 21 initial National Projects encompass crucial components such as: Policy and regulations. Business model innovation with private sector. Scaled-up Financing Digital and knowledge management Monitoring and Evaluation.

The program is supporting a total of 21 African countries: Angola, Burkina Faso, Comoros, Djibouti, Ethiopia, Eswatini, Madagascar, Malawi, Nigeria, Somalia, Sudan, Benin, Chad, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, São Tome and Principe, Zambia, Burundi, Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), and Liberia. These 21 countries host 396 million people without electricity access and more than two thirds of the total unelectrified population of Africa. They also represent a diverse cross-section of African countries: both large as well as smaller markets; Anglophone, Francophone, and Lusophone countries; small island developing states; and countries in post-crisis contexts. This can create a rich and diverse mix of contexts, perspectives and experiences in the program. UNDP's modelling estimates reveal that the AMP presents a substantial investment opportunity of $65 billion in the private sector for solar-battery minigrids, with the potential to electrify 265 million people by 2030. Under Component 2 of the National Projects, the AMP supports investments in various types of minigrid pilots, including greenfield minigrids and hybridized diesel minigrids, aimed at demonstrating cost-reduction opportunities and promoting the renewable fraction of power generation.

Through its comprehensive interventions, close collaboration with governments, communities, and partners, the AMP is poised to contribute significantly to realizing the minigrid opportunity and advancing the interconnected SDGs across Africa. The transformative impact of constructing 110,000 minigrids can be witnessed in bringing electricity to schools, clinics, and businesses, driving economic growth and fostering community development.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Off-grid renewable energy systems, such as Solar Home Systems (SHS) and mini-grids, are effective solutions for expanding energy access in underserved areas. They directly contribute to socioeconomic development by supporting productive uses like solar-powered water pumps and equipment for microenterprises.

Clean cooking technologies, including biogas and solar-powered e-cooking, are transforming cooking practices and waste management in rural communities. These innovations reduce dependence on traditional biomass fuels, cut greenhouse gas emissions, and open up new economic opportunities.

Heating and cooling solutions, like solar water heaters, bioclimatic designs, and geothermal energy, enhance energy efficiency and strengthen climate resilience. Additionally, solar-powered freezers and cold rooms improve food preservation, reduce waste, and provide income-generating opportunities for rural communities.
